720634f-a.text:
Irving Place, at and adjoining S.W. corner of 17th Street, showing 49 Irving Place, the corner house which is supposed to have been at one time the home of Washington Irving, and is accordingly known as the Washington Irving house. The little railing around the roof of the house is not seen in photographs as early as 1909. Adjoining 47 Irving Place may be seen part of the north wall of the Westminster Hotel, which will be demolished in 1909.
About 1900.
0ift of W. M. Van Der Weyde.
1N~ NW  2NE4  Ny. 77 822
(2)
The same, a generation later. The Borgfeldt Building, shown in part at the left, was erected in 1909 on the site of the Westminster Hotel.
August 30, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

720634f-b.text:
Irving Place, at and adjoining S.W. corner of 17th Street, showing 49 Irving Place, the corner house which is supposed to have been at one time the home of Washington Irving, and is accordingly known as the Washington Irving house. The little railing around the roof of the house is not seen in photographs as early as 1909. Adjoining 47 Irving Place may be seen part of the north wall of the Westminster Hotel, which will be demolished in 1909.

720635f.text:
Irving Place, at, adjoinin; and south of the S.W. corner of East 17th Street. Also shown is East 17th Street, south side, west from Irving P1ace, to, but not including Union Square, East. Corner building shown, No. 49 Irving Place, is the Washington Irving House, and now is the home of
the Author's League Club.
About 1912.
Underwood & Undcrwood.

720643f-a.text:
(1)
Irving Place, east side, from 54 Irving Place, just north of 17th Street, to the S.E. corner of 19th Street. The former Huyler Confectionery Works are shown at and adjoining the S.W. corner of 18th Street. The builcing first occupied by this company in this location
was the corner house (1885 or a little earlier).
The sign on 54 Irving Place, at the extreme right, is that of a
Consumers' Co-operative Cafeteria.
July 3, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
982-86 Irving Place,East side and Northwards from East 19th St. to
Grammeroy Park.
August 22nd,1940.
P.L.Sperr,
No Neproductions.

(1)
Irving Place, east side, from 54 Irving Place, just north of 17th Street, to the S.E. corner of 19th Street. The former Huyler Confectionery Works are shown at and adjoining the S.W. corner of 18th Street. The builcing first occupied by this company in this location

720633f-a.text:
Irving Place at East 17th Street, south east corner showing  Washington Irving High School for Girls.
Board cf Education, N Y.C.
EDIT LINE INPRATIE.  April 15, 1231.

720638f-a.text:
49-47 Irving Place, (left) at and adjoining the S.W. corner of East 17th Street. The corner structure, No. 49, with its entrance on 17th Street, is supposed to have been the residence of Washington Irving and is popularly known as the Washington Irving House. Shown on the right and north of same is a 3-story building, No. 120 East 17th Street.
July 1937.
GeBrge D. Chinn.

720628f-a.text:
Irving Place, north from but not including East 17th Street, showing road bed being repaired by the W.P.A. Intersection appearing in the foreground is East 18th Street.
September 2, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

720640f.text:
55 Irving Place, west side, between East 17th and East 18th Streets, showing the O. Henry House, in which the great American short story writer lived and worked.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

720642f-a.text:
Irving Place, east side, north from No. 58 a point midway between East 17th and 18th Streets, and across the latter,showing pavement conditions in front of the now demolished (1937) Huylers Confectionery Plant, Nos. 60-64, at the S.E. corner of East 18th Street.
August 7, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

720641f-a.text:
55 Irving Place, west side, between East 17th and 18th Streets, showing the O'Henry House, in which the great American short story writer
lived and worked.
July 1937.
George D. Chinn.

720632f-a.text:
Irving Place (foreground), east side, north from E. 17th Street (right, not seen) to Gramercy Park, showing an outdoor parking lot at the former Nersey Chocolate Go. plant site. Across same appear buildings on the north side of E. 18th Street,
east from Irving Place.
February 4, 1938
P.L. Sperr

720639f-a.text:
54 and 56 (right to left) Irving Place,adjoining and north of the N. E. corner of E. 17th Stret, showing two 3 story former private dwellings. That, with the bay window is now occupied by the Cooperative Cafeteria, an enterprise long associated with the
wife of Norman Thomas, the Socialist.
June 1938
  George D. Chinn
A2NA NA 2272

720636f-a.text:
49 Irving Place, at the S.W. corner of E. 17th Street, showing a commemorative tablet on the 17th Street side of same. This shows a bas-relief of a profile of Washington IIrving, who was supposed to have
lived and worked here.
July 1937.
ift of Geo. D. Chinn.

720637f-a.text:
47-49 Irving Place, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of East 17th Street. The corner building; No. 49 with its entrance on 17th Street, was supposed to have been the residence of Washington Irving and is popularly known as the Washington Irving HIouse. The Washington Irving Hlgh School for Girls, across Irving Place (east side between 16th and 17th Streets), erected a commemorative bust of Washington Irving in 1936, which faces this
landmark.
1936.
V.P.A. Photo.
Pederal Writers Project.

720644f-a.text:
Irving Place, west side, south from East 18th to 17th Streets, as
seen thru clearance at the S.E. corner of 18th Street, (former site of Huyler's]  Chocolate Co. Building.
December 23, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
